text: The first wave of customers pushes in before noon. Snowmelt is tracked across the floor, chair legs scraping in a series of small, popping sounds.
I’m still deciding who to serve first when Alicia ties an apron around her waist—like fastening the final clasp of armor.
“Two tables of stew, one table of bread, one table of hot wine.”
“How did you—”
“I can smell it.”
She lifts a tray and moves off. Her pace isn’t fast, but never wastes a step; the tray in her hands is so steady it might as well be nailed to the air.
Someone at one table laughs and shouts something crude in her direction.
“If you’re drinking, drink.”
“If not, shut your mouth and don’t let the soup get cold.”
The man’s grin stiffens. Someone beside him hastily tugs his sleeve. The whole table goes quiet, as if they’ve suddenly remembered a taboo.
She doesn’t look at them again. She sets down the wine, taps the table lightly with a finger.
A single *clink*—like striking a bell that means *this ends here*.
“You’ll scare off customers if you do business like that.”
“I won’t.”
“The ones who scare easily usually can’t afford to pay anyway.”
After saying it, she actually seems a little satisfied—the briefest spark of something like *this is new*.
She turns to the next table, movements sharp and efficient, like switching formations.
Pouring drinks, refilling stew, taking money, wiping tables—each step looks drilled into muscle memory.
I hand her a plate of freshly cooked stew. When she takes it, her fingers brush mine, pausing for just a moment.
“See?”
“This is what I want.”
“What?”
“Not blades. Not blood.”
“You hand me a plate, I put it on a table—and then it’s done.”
Her voice is light, but it feels like she’s forcing down the words *I haven’t lived like this in a long time*.
By mid-afternoon, the crowd thins. She slides the last coin into my palm, like turning in spoils after a fight.
“Being the tavern mistress isn’t bad.”
“At least the rules are simple here: customers are fed, drinks are hot, and you’re not hurt.”
When she says *you’re not hurt*, her gaze drifts to my hand, unconsciously checking—like inspecting something she has to keep intact.
For a moment, she looks like she’s back in the role she’s truly good at—not serving plates, but guarding something and refusing to let it break, even at the cost of her life.
